Provides methodologies for enumerating and exploiting privesc vectors including SUID binaries, sudo permissions, capabilities, kernel exploits, cron jobs, and common misconfigurations. Includes systematic approach to capturing root flags.

security_audit.summary: Pure knowledge-base documentation file with no executable code, no network activity, no file access, and no data collection. Contains only instructional content for authorized security research in controlled environments.

content.value_statement: Privilege escalation is essential for penetration testing but requires systematic methodology. This knowledge base provides step-by-step techniques for escalating from low-privilege to root access on Linux systems, including sudo abuse, SUID binaries, capabilities, and kernel exploits.
actual_capabilities: Identify privilege escalation vectors through systematic enumeration
Exploit sudo misconfigurations using GTFOBins techniques
Find and leverage SUID binaries for root access
Discover and exploit cron job misconfigurations
Locate and capture root flags after successful escalation
limitations: Contains no executable code - provides only methodology guidance
Designed for controlled lab environments, not production systems
Requires existing initial access to target system
Kernel exploits may crash systems and should be last resort

prompt_templates.title: Quick check
prompt_templates.prompt: What can I run with sudo on this system? Check using sudo -l and identify exploitable binaries.

prompt_templates.title: Find SUID
prompt_templates.prompt: Find all SUID binaries on this system using find / -perm -4000 and identify ones that can be exploited via GTFOBins.

prompt_templates.title: Enumeration
prompt_templates.prompt: Run comprehensive privilege escalation enumeration. Check capabilities, cron jobs, writable files, and running processes.

prompt_templates.title: Exploitation

best_practices: Start with quick manual checks before running resource-intensive enumeration tools
Always verify root access with id or whoami before claiming success
Document successful exploitation method for learning and reporting
anti_patterns: Attempting kernel exploits before checking simpler vectors like sudo or SUID
Skipping verification and assuming root access without confirmation
Using the same failed approach repeatedly instead of trying alternatives

faq.question: What is the most common privilege escalation vector?
faq.answer: Sudo misconfigurations are the most common. Always check sudo -l first as it often leads to immediate root access.

faq.question: How long should enumeration take before moving to kernel exploits?
faq.answer: Kernel exploits are last resort. Try quick wins (2-5 min), then automated tools (5-15 min), then alternatives before kernel exploits.

faq.question: Does this skill execute commands on my system?
faq.answer: No. This is a knowledge base that provides methodology guidance. Commands must be executed by the user or AI agent.

faq.question: Can this be used on production systems?
faq.answer: No. This is designed for controlled lab environments with intentionally vulnerable targets for security research.

faq.question: What if enumeration finds no obvious vectors?
faq.answer: Re-examine results more carefully. Check linpeas output for yellow/red items, search for credentials in files, and review environment variables.

faq.question: How is this different from automated privesc tools?
faq.answer: This provides structured methodology and decision-making guidance. Automated tools like linpeas find vectors; this knowledge base teaches how to exploit them.
